data.title: Better IntelliSense for TypeScript/JavaScript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

I think IntelliSense could show more documentation than it currently does. Take the following example (concrete feature requests are marked with a leading "‚ù§Ô∏è"):

``` typescript
/**
 * Add numbers!
 * @param a First number.
 * @param b Second number.
 */
function add(a: number, b: number): number {
  return a + b;
}

/**
 * This is a.
 */
const a = 1;

const c = add(a, 2);

/**
 * This is some object.
 */
interface SomeObject {
  /**
   * This is foo.
   */
  foo: string;
  /**
   * This is bar.
   */
  bar: string;
}

/*
 * This is an instance of some object.
 */
const someObject: SomeObject = {
  /**
   * Test.
   */
  foo: 'foo',
  bar: 'bar'
};

const foo2 = someObject.foo;
```

And now let us step through each statement and look if it could be improved.

**1. Function signature**

``` typescript
function add(a: number, b: number): number {
```
- Hovering over `add` shows `Add numbers!`. 
- Hovering over `a` shows `First number.`.
- Hovering over `b` shows `Second number.`.

Great. Everything works üëç 

**2. Function body**

``` typescript
  return a + b;
```
- Hovering over `a` shows `First number.`.
- Hovering over `b` shows `Second number.`.

Great. Everything works üëç 

**3. Variable declaration**

``` typescript
const a = 1;
```
- Hovering over `a` shows `This is a.`.

Great. Everything works üëç 

**4. Function call**

``` typescript
const c = add(a, 2);
```
- Hovering over `c` shows nothing.
  - This is expected. We have no description like for `const a`.
  - ‚ùì However... it doesn't seem we can document return values from a function call properly. Adding `* @return This is the sum.` to the `function add` documentation shows the return annotation as part of the description. But it would be nice, if hovering over `c` would show `This is the sum.` instead.
  - If we'd add a description to `const c` like we did for `const a` (e.g. `This is c.`) _and_ we add a proper `@return` annotation to `function add` it would be nice if IntelliSense would show _both_ description when hovering over `c`: `This is c.` and `This is the sum.` (maybe with a small visual delimiter between both descriptions.).
- Hovering over `add` shows `Add numbers!`.
- Hovering over `a` shows `This is a.`.
  - It would be nice, if it would also show `First number.`.
- Hovering over `2` shows nothing.
  - It would be nice, if it would show `Second number.`.

‚ù§Ô∏è  **Request 1**: It would be nice to show `@return` annotations correctly in IntelliSense.
‚ù§Ô∏è  **Request 2**: It would be nice to _additionally_ show `@param` and `@return` annotations alongside with descriptions of variable declarations or _at least_  as a fallback, if a variable has no _own_ description.

**5. Interface**

``` typescript
interface SomeObject {
```
- Hovering over `SomeObject` shows `This is some object.`.

Great. Everything works üëç 

**6. Property in interface**

``` typescript
  foo: string;
```
- Hovering over `foo` shows `This is foo.`.

Great. Everything works üëç 

**7. Object with interface**

``` typescript
const someObject: SomeObject = {
```
- Hovering over `someObject` shows nothing.
  - I'd expect to see `This is an instance of some object.`.
- Hovering over `SomeObject` shows `This is some object.`.

‚ù§Ô∏è  **Request 3**: It would be nice to show the description of an object using an interface.

**8. Properties of an object with interface**

``` typescript
  foo: 'foo',
  bar: 'bar'
```
- Hovering over `foo` shows `Test.`.
  - It could also show `This is foo.`.
- Hovering over `bar` shows nothing.
  - It could at least show `This is bar.`.

‚ù§Ô∏è  **Request 4**: It would be nice to _additionally_ show property descriptions from an interface _and_ descriptions of properties in a concrete object or _at least_  as a fallback, if the property of an object has no _own_ description.

**9. Using properties of an object with interface**

``` typescript
const foo2 = someObject.foo;
```
- Hovering over `foo` shows `This is foo.`.
  - It could also show `Test.`. (üí° This was very surprising for me that IntelliSense used `This is foo.` instead of `Test.` here. However... best thing would be to show both.)
- Hovering over `foo2` shows nothing.
  - It looks like the the type is correctly inferred and it would be nice if the descriptions could be reused here, too. (E.g. `Test.` and `This is foo.`)
- Hovering over `someObject` shows nothing.
  - It should show `This is an instance of some object.` (and could additionally show `This is some object.`).

‚ù§Ô∏è  **Request 5**: When using properties of an object which are documented in the object itself _and_ in the interface it would be nice if the description from the object declaration could be shown (because it is probably more custom to the current use case) _or_ show both descriptions.
‚ù§Ô∏è  **Request 6**: When types can be inferred it would be nice to infer descriptions, too.

data.title: Render problem under high DPI monitor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-insider, 
- OS Version: Win10 Pro

I got two different text render styles, one is blurry, and another is clear.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/628293/15003152/68b30c4e-11db-11e6-961d-c06e76d8ebba.png)

You can see middle window is more blurry than both left and right window.
My monitor size is 13 inches, with 1920x1080 resolution. Display zoom level is **125%**, and I've set up **Code - Insiders.exe**'s compatible settings, and checked '**Disable display zoom under high DPI**' (may be this, as I'm using a Chinese edition). 

My settings:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/628293/15003219/37d97896-11dc-11e6-9131-109af8bf26a4.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/628293/15003227/5276f0fc-11dc-11e6-9ac0-29e46431a86f.png)

data.title: Tooltips stop working after opening context menu in the editor
data.body:
When pointing to program objects (variables, methods, classes, etc) by mouse, vscode shows tooltip with information about it:

C#

![vscode-csharp-tooltips](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18505072/15002747/4e642c5c-11ad-11e6-8f7d-142ce54f9b4f.png)

Golang

![vscode-go-tooltips](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18505072/15002751/55a8f254-11ad-11e6-8d25-c8df712bf29a.png)

Or just json file with vscode settings.

But after opening context menu by right mouse button click tooltips stop working.

![vscode-context-menu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18505072/15002774/97defc4a-11ad-11e6-82db-1f4e1bffccfe.png)

Pointing any object doesn't trigger tooltips anymore. It starts working again after restart of vscode.
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-insider (Commit 1f065770).
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.10586 and Fedora 23.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start vscode.
2. Open File -> Preferences -> User Settings (or any Go/C# file).
3. Point to `editor.fontFamily`. It triggers tooltip "Controls the font family".
4. Press right mouse button to open context menu.
5. Point to `editor.fontFamily` again. There's no tooltip.

data.title: Git folder shows .VC.db* files as modified
data.body:
VSCode Version: 1.0
OS Version: OS X Elcapitan
Steps to Reproduce:

Open a git repository
I have configured
$ git config --global core.excludesfile ~/.gitignore_global
and added them to .gitignore_global it does not work

.vscode, and .VC. files are shown as modified,
These files should be auto ignored

(Same as issue https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5868)
Had to create this one since I did not get a response on the updates.

It seems some translations regress after alpha updates. Is this expected?

data.title: Multiple monitors: focus is not put to window when opened on different monitor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

Prerequisites:
1. Configure VS Code as your `git` editor.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a project in VS Code and make some changes.
2. Switch to your terminal and `git commit` those changes.
3. A new VS Code window opens for you to write your commit message, but the focus is on your original project window and not on the window that just opened for `git`.

data.title: Can't insert nbsp character
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 

```
Version 1.0.0
Commit fa6d0f03813dfb9df4589c30121e9fcffa8a8ec8
Date 2016-04-13T14:08:36.599Z
Shell 0.35.6
Renderer 45.0.2454.85
Node 4.1.1
```
- OS Version:

```
Windows Version 10.0.10586
```

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open an existing text file, or create a new file.
2. Change keyboard language to Persian.
3. Press `Ctrl + Shift + 2` to insert nbsp.

Prior versions of vscode inserted nbsp in the text without any problem, However the latest version doesn't seem to be able to insert nbsp into the text.

data.title: Peek Definition to Find all References closes peek window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Right click a variable > Peek Definition
2. Right click the same variable > Find all References

This closes the peek window and does not open the Find all References window. The reverse (Find all references to Peek Definition) also closes the window.

data.title: Rename Symbol hidden under Peek/References window
data.body:

data.title: Unable to read long message in debug console.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app and open folder which contains Aspnet console app.
2. Configure for debugging.
3. Start debugging  and verify debug console window.
Actual: Long message is truncated and user unable to read complete message from debug console.
Expected: Message should not be truncated and wrap properly. or Mouse hove should show message contents.

The program 'c:\src\TestCSharpProj\TestCSharpWithVSCode/bin/Debug/dnx451/win7-x64/TestCSharpWithVSCode.exe' has exited with code -1 (0xffffffff).

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14988198/b72f099c-1107-11e6-94a6-0da5d8887268.png)

data.title: Open files are not auto-saved, when extension installation restarts the VS Code

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open and edit a file.
2. Install an extension that requires restart.
3. Click restart button.
4. The changes you've made to the file is not auto-saved and they are gone.

data.title: VSCode doesn't find app.ts if it isn't in project root
data.body:
<!--
Thank you for contributing to TypeScript! Please review this checklist
       before submitting your issue.
[ ] Many common issues and suggestions are addressed in the FAQ
     https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/FAQ
[ ] Search for duplicates before logging new issues
    https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue
[ ] Questions are best asked and answered at Stack Overflow
    http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/typescript

For bug reports, please include the information below.
__________________________________________________________ -->

**TypeScript Version:** 

1.8.10

**VSCode Version:**
1.0.0

**OS**
Linux 4.4.8-300.fc23.x86_64
Fedora 23
Gnome 3.18.2

**Project structure**

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ dist
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.js
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.js.map
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ other code
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ node_modules
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ npm-shrinkwrap.json
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ readme.md
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.ts
‚îÇ¬†¬† ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ other code
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tsconfig.json
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tsd.json
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tslint.json
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ typings
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.d.ts

**tsconfig.json**

``` json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "noImplicitAny": false,
    "removeComments": true,
    "preserveConstEnums": true,
    "sourceMap": true,
    "sourceRoot": "./src",
    "module": "commonjs",
    "target": "es5",
    "outDir": "dist"
  },
  "filesGlob": [
    "src/**/*.ts",
    "src/app.ts"
  ],
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules",
    "dist",
    "doc",
    "Gruntfile.js"
  ]
}
```

**Expected behavior:**
vscode should look for the app.ts in the sourceRoot
And "activate" intelisense

**Actual behavior:** 
vscode doesn't find the app.ts and because of this intelisense doesn't work

**Edit**
added the intelisense part to the behavior describtion

data.title: runtime arguments are interpreted by "Electron Helper" as files

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: alpha

I tried to add a runtime argument '--debug-brk' when VS Code launches node-debug by setting the `runtimeArgs` attribute in package.json. This half-works: node seems to be launched in debug-brk mode and I can attach to it with VS Code. But then an exception occurs because node tries to execute the '--debug-brk' as a file:

![2016-05-03 17-09-24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/14987933/eac372bc-1151-11e6-8c2b-7377597f79af.png)

Could it be that the '--debug-brk' option is passed twice or in the wrong position? IIRC you are using Alex's script to reroute stdin/stdout through some named pipe. Could that be the problem?

data.title: default light theme - UI text hard to read
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0
- OS Version: Win7

Steps to Reproduce:
select File>Preferences>Color Theme: Light (Visual Studio) or Light + (default light)

Look at the colors in the file explorer in the left panel - not the editor panel.
The text is light grey on slightly lighter grey background.
This is very hard to read.
- how to change that?
- where is the theme file located?
- what to change in this file to set text color to BLACK?

Please help people with weak eyesight.

data.title: Cursor and focus gone after toggling the side bar.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.3

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file and place the cursor somewhere.
2. Hide side bar (CMD-B). Cursor remains at position --> OK
3. Show side bar again. Cursor is gone and the focus is set on the Working Files panel of the side bar. --> Not OK

data.title: Emmet Stylus snippets not working
data.body:
The Stylus snippets that come out of the box with Emmet do not work in VSCode, while the default setting in the 'preferences.json' (that is nowhere to be found) of Emmet 'css.syntaxes -
List of syntaxes that should be treated as CSS dialects.' has .styl
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 Enterprise

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a .styl file
2. Add a CSS selector: ex. #test
3. Type pos:a and press TAB

**Expected result:** expands to 'position absolute' or 'position: absolute;'
**Actual result:** nothing happens

data.title: Passing arguments to preLaunchTask in launch.json
data.body:
I am using `launch.json` to debug .Net Core Application in VS code. 
Debugger configuration uses `"preLaunchTask": "build"` to build application before starting, but the problem is that I have several projects in my solution that I want to debug, so I have duplicated `launch.json` configurations for every single executable project in my solution. With this scenario `build` preLaunchTask is not working. I need to pass my project's directory to `build` task.

Is there anyway to pass arguments to `preLaunchTask` from `launch.json`?

data.title: [loc][Query][VSCode] Ampersand position
data.body:
Hi, we have a question from a translator. Could you help please?

Source:
&&Reopen Closed File

File Name:
src\vs\workbench\electron-main\menus.nls.resx

Resource ID:
".resx", 0; "miReopenClosedFile"

Query:
Please confirm the two ampersands in the source string should be inserted in the source as is.  inho.chung  4/27/2016 1:27:00 PM

data.title: Cannot keybind "workbench.action.files.newFile"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create keybinding snippet:
   {
       "key": "ctrl+alt+n",     "command": "workbench.action.files.newFile",
                                   "when": ""
   }
2. When keys ("ctrl+alt+n) are pressed while in Explorer message pop ups:
   "No handler found for the command "workbench.action.files.newFile", An extension may be missing active event."

I have checked VSCode base and I can see the code for :*\* workbench.action.files.newFile**

[fileActions.ts](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/3ac0ead70531884389000844bb505c56a193d48e/src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/fileActions.ts)
Line 472: NewFileAction 

What am I missing? Do I need to restrict with when, but never the less, error says it is not finding handler at all...

data.title: Not getting any response while running DNX command multiple times.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create Aspnet C# console app using yeoman.
2. Set proper dotnet environment and verify response using dnx restore and dnx run.
3. Launch VSCode and open project folder.
4. Configure launch.json, task.json.
5. Perform DNX restore and DNX run command and verify response.
6, Now update project.json and add "debugType": "portable" under compilationOptions.
7. Build project and verify if any error message or warning is showing up.
8. Now try to perform "DNX restore" and "DNX: run command" operation from command palette and verify app behavior.

Actual: DNX command is responding very first time only and for further dnx execution there is no response.
Expected: User should get proper response when executing DNX command from command palette.

Note: Each time user needs to reload window or restart app to get DNX response.

![dnxissuenew](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14974661/9e5a0a30-10ac-11e6-958e-bf95d4f551e3.gif)

data.title: How to set keywords highlight for each language ?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: windows 10

I downloaded a theme from "http://tmtheme-editor.herokuapp.com/#!/editor/theme/Eclipse", but it seems that some setting have no effect ?

![1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17231597/14974152/870cb20c-1123-11e6-9fe5-17b3b19c44ae.png)
